ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Technologies used for graphic designing.
Intro to procedural modeling and texturing
Procedural modeling, texturing, and animation techniques and how to implement them

the building blocks of many computer graphics algorithms, history of computer graphics and developments in the field
how to code and script in Blender
Blender software and writing Python plug-ins for Blender using their API
I learned about developments in computer graphics research and did a lot of scripting in Blender.

In this course, I learned about different types of procedural modeling in computer graphics.  The course placed a greater emphasis on the graphical results that procedural modeling allows than on the algorithms and mathematical techniques necessary to achieve the results.
Scripting in blender

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Basically a self-taught class

The material is very cool especially after you successfully implement the techniques and see visual results yourself. Zach the TA is very nice and offers a lot of meaningful contribution to the class. However, the class was a bit disorganized and there wasn't a lot of meaningful input from the professor herself. Personally I felt that student presentations on the paper readings in lieu of proper lectures given by the professor weren't all that effective.

This class would be much better if it was a lecture or seminar led by the professor, rather than a presentation based class. Every class was led by students, so we never really got to hear from Professor Dorsey.

Strengths: goes through a gamut of different topics, great survey of computer graphics as a whole
Weaknesses: little guidance for each assignment, also there was a lot of student teaching which I found less effective; I wish I had heard from Professor Dorsey more directly
I learned a lot about how graphics work behind the scenes, but I wish the format could be adjusted so it's not just listening to student presentations on weekly readings that are assigned

The learning curve for Blender is quite steep for someone who has never used Blender before. Having tutorials during class for key Blender functionality could have been helpful. A strength of this course is that it is project-based, so you can apply your skills to your interests.

I enjoyed the presentations given by guest speakers over the course of the semester.  I liked having the opportunity to give a presentation for one of the lectures:  giving a presentation helped with my understanding of the material.  Also, hearing other students give their presentations was helpful in that it allowed me to see the same material covered from different perspectives.
I hope the professor could teach some technical stuff rather than the students giving presentations all the time.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes
Could learn just as much by reading classic procedural modeling and texturing research papers.

This is another one of those you-get-what-you-put-in sort of classes. The professor doesn't give lectures but instead let students present the readings (which, depending on who's doing the presentation, can be hit or miss). Also do not expect to get any meaningful support from the professor through office hours. That being said, the topics are super cool and if you are sufficiently self-driven you can get a lot out of it.

Not in its current form. I did not like the presentation based aspect of the class and felt that I was not tested on the information we talked about in class. Projects were pretty separate from the topics in class, especially towards the end. This class is very much of the "you get what you put in" style.
I wouldn't really recommend it unless they're really interested in computer graphics; it can be hard to get through otherwise. If you do like computer graphics, though, this is for you.

I would not recommend taking this class unless you have a strong background in math and are familiar with understanding computer science academic papers. You should also be very motivated to do learn things on your own without the help of the instructor. Every week we were assigned readings to summarize, and students would present them in class. The professor did very minimal teaching. The workload is small, but I feel like I did not learn much from this class. This is also crosslisted as a grad course, and the grad students clearly had a better grasp of things than many of the other undergrads.

Yes if you're interested in graphics. I'm not sure I would've enjoyed this class if I didn't want to go into a career in animation, just since it's so reading-centric, which is different from most other CS classes here.
Yes, if you're interested in computer graphics, especially if you enjoy approaching topics in the area from a research lens.

I would recommend this course to other students, even ones who do not have any prior experience with computer graphics.  This was my first time taking a graphics course.  Most of the time, when I wanted to know how to do something in Blender for a project, I needed to search for the answer myself.  Finding the answer was easy most of the time, though.  Occasions when I felt genuinely helpless were rare.
No
